skill.name: startup-financial-modeling
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create financial projections", "build a financial model", "forecast revenue", "calculate burn rate", "estimate runway", "model cash flow", or requests 3-5 year financial planning for a startup.
skill.summary: Build comprehensive 3-5 year financial models with revenue projections, cost structures, cash flow analysis, and scenario planning for early-stage startups.
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing financial modeling formulas and templates. All static findings are false positives: markdown code blocks with financial formulas were misidentified as code execution, and no cryptographic or reconnaissance patterns exist.

medium_findings.title: External Commands - False Positive
medium_findings.description: Markdown code blocks containing financial formulas were misidentified as Ruby/shell backtick execution. Examples include MRR/ARR calculations and runway formulas displayed in code fences for documentation.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: All detected patterns are financial formulas displayed in markdown code fences for documentation purposes. No actual code execution, shell commands, or dynamic evaluation exists.

low_findings.title: Weak Cryptographic Algorithm - False Positive
low_findings.description: Static scanner incorrectly flagged text as weak cryptographic algorithms. No cryptographic code or MD5/SHA references exist in this financial documentation file.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: File contains no cryptographic algorithms, hashing functions, or encryption code. This is pure financial documentation with no executable code whatsoever.

low_findings.title: System Reconnaissance - False Positive
low_findings.description: References to 'Revenue â‰  cash' and 'payment terms' were misidentified as system reconnaissance. These are legitimate cash flow timing concepts in financial modeling.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: These lines discuss revenue timing and payment terms as part of cash flow analysis, not system commands or reconnaissance activity.

content.value_statement: Create comprehensive 3-5 year financial models with revenue projections, burn rate calculations, runway analysis, and scenario planning to support fundraising and strategic decisions.
actual_capabilities: Build 3-5 year financial projections using cohort-based revenue modeling
Calculate burn rate, runway, and cash flow positions
Model SaaS, marketplace, e-commerce, and services business models
Analyze unit economics including CAC, LTV, and payback period
Integrate fundraising scenarios with milestone-based planning
limitations: Does not execute code or access external financial data sources
Does not validate user-provided numbers against actual market data
Does not generate interactive spreadsheets or downloadable files
Cannot replace professional financial advice or accounting services

use_cases.title: Create pitch deck financial projections
use_cases.description: Build investor-ready financial projections with 3-5 year forecasts, scenario analysis, and key metrics for fundraising presentations and board meetings.
use_cases.target_user: Founders preparing for investor meetings or pitch decks

use_cases.title: Model cash runway and funding needs
use_cases.description: Calculate monthly burn rate, runway duration, and determine optimal funding amounts based on milestones and growth targets.
use_cases.target_user: CFOs and finance leads planning fundraising strategy

use_cases.title: Build operational budget plans
use_cases.description: Create detailed cost structures, hiring plans, and expense budgets aligned with revenue growth and business stage.
use_cases.target_user: Startup operators managing annual planning and budgets

prompt_templates.title: Basic financial model request
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a 3-year financial model for a SaaS startup. Include monthly projections for revenue (with cohort-based assumptions), expenses by category (COGS, S&M, R&D, G&A), headcount plan, cash flow, burn rate, and runway. Use a conservative scenario.
prompt_templates.scenario: Create foundational financial projections from scratch

prompt_templates.title: SaaS-specific projections
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a detailed SaaS financial model with monthly revenue projections based on new customer acquisition, retention rates by cohort, ARPU, expansion revenue, and churn. Include S&M spend with CAC payback calculations. Show metrics: ARR, gross margin, LTV/CAC ratio, and net retention.
prompt_templates.scenario: Model subscription business with unit economics focus

prompt_templates.title: Scenario comparison analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a three-scenario financial model (conservative, base, optimistic) for a [STAGE] startup. For each scenario, vary customer acquisition rate, churn, pricing, and CAC by reasonable ranges. Compare runway, funding needs, and key milestones across scenarios.
prompt_templates.scenario: Compare multiple planning scenarios with sensitivities

prompt_templates.title: Fundraising integration model
prompt_templates.prompt: Model a Series A fundraising scenario: current metrics, funding amount needed to reach 18-month runway, pre-money valuation based on comparable companies, dilution analysis, and use of funds allocation across product, sales, and operations.
prompt_templates.scenario: Integrate fundraising scenarios with equity planning

output_examples.input: Build a 3-year SaaS financial model starting with 10 customers at $500 ARPU, growing 15% monthly, with 85% monthly retention, $10K CAC, and $150K initial runway.
output: Year 1 Summary: 150 customers, $900K ARR by Month 12, $180K net burn, 8 months runway
Year 2 Summary: 1,200 customers, $7.2M ARR by Month 24, approaching cash flow neutral
Year 3 Summary: 6,500 customers, $39M ARR by Month 36, profitable operations
Key Metrics: LTV/CAC of 4.2x, CAC payback of 14 months, gross margin of 82%

best_practices: Use cohort-based revenue modeling with realistic retention curves rather than simple growth multipliers
Include 20% buffers on expense estimates and fully-loaded compensation calculations
Model conservative scenarios first to understand cash constraints before exploring growth cases
Validate assumptions against comparable companies at similar funding stages
anti_patterns: Using linear revenue projections without accounting for churn and retention dynamics
Ignoring cash conversion timing and treating revenue recognition as immediate cash inflow
Creating single-scenario models without understanding downside risks and runway implications
Overlooking fully-loaded employee costs including benefits, taxes, and ramp time

faq.question: What time horizon should I model for my startup?
faq.answer: Model 3 years in detail with monthly granularity, then add 4-5 years at annual level. Investors typically want to see monthly projections for the first 18-24 months where assumptions are most uncertain.

faq.question: How do I estimate customer acquisition cost for my model?
faq.answer: Calculate CAC as total sales and marketing spend divided by new customers acquired. Include team compensation, tools, ad spend, and agency costs. For early-stage SaaS, expect $5K-20K CAC depending on sales complexity.

faq.question: What metrics do investors care about most?
faq.answer: For SaaS: ARR growth rate, gross margin, net revenue retention, and LTV/CAC ratio. For any stage: runway, burn multiple, and path to profitability. Match metrics to your funding stage and sector norms.

faq.question: How should I model headcount costs?
faq.answer: Use fully-loaded costs: salary plus 30-40% for benefits, taxes, and equipment. Factor in 3-6 month hiring timeline and 3-6 month ramp to productivity. Include attrition of 10-15% annually.

faq.question: How do I calculate runway accurately?
faq.answer: Runway = current cash balance / average monthly net burn. Account for timing differences between revenue recognition and actual cash collection. Model conservative burn if revenue timing is uncertain.

faq.question: Should I include funding rounds in my projections?
faq.answer: Model funding as a scenario variable. Show pre-funding runway, then model post-funding operations. Investors want to see how their capital extends runway and enables milestone achievement.
